Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2012 04:59AM silentbell wrote: L & J's mom, There is a simple test to confirm excess lactic acid in your system.  While sitting up hold your arms straight out and your fingers straight up as if you were directing traffic and giving traffic the "stop"sign.  You will need an observer.  With arms and hands just so, shut your eyes and if your arms drop you have excess lactic acid.  In my wife's case it was liver related.  They gave her something (can't recall at the moment) that made her "go" (ugh) and really empty out.  Important to note, while it gets rid of the acid it also wipes out the bodies potassium and you will need to replenish it.  I hope this helps.  Hang in there and good luck!

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 06:51PM silentbell wrote: Ok Glenna,  pretty cakes come from Kentucky and I'm sure to regret this but... Good luck making sense of my ramblings, but here goes, first night on the ship and we hit the nightclub joint and oh man, my wife is out of control, she's kissing me like a homeless person on the dance floor(they are real good kissers because they probe around for loose pieces of food) and going absolutely crazy.  When we wake up I'm the first one dressed and I look at my cell phone clock and it says 3:00.  While I wait for my wife to get ready i grab a beer, then another.  When we head out to eat i'm luggin my beer and we get to the restaurant with the white tablecloths, folded napkins and pastry tray guy and I notice everyone is eating breakfast.  When the waiter comes over I ask him what time it is and he says 8:00.  Cell phones lose their signal when out to sea and damn right I finished my beer. Now we have left Bermuda and are sailing home and we hit the night club again, when the club band takes a break the lead singer makes her way to our table and says "Hi how are you doing?"  Great I say and then she says "How are you Mrs. Silentbell?" to which my wife says "okay how are you?".......After she leaves it's "How does she know my name?"  So I say "I'd blame it on the brain mets."  After an hour she hits the restroom, when she comes back she says "While I'm at the sink, the lady next to me says "Your the lady from the first night, you were adorable."  We laugh and she goes   "What the hell happened that first night?"  I say "You owned this place."  I used the word adorable as an adjective 3 times and then from the looks I got, I remembered I'm not good at sleeping with one eye open. First cruise ever, big fun poolside with the mudslides.  Weather was great and my wife was adorable
Posts.Title: Always something.... silentbell bhd1

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2012 05:16PM silentbell wrote: Hey you guys, Thanks for the kind words.  Just got back from Dana Farber and didn't get tx because white blood counts were too low for the trials standards.  They say next week everything should be fine (count wise) and we'll get the tx in, maybe a reduced dose if necessary.  Markers rising a little and a reschedule of scans means they'll be done at the end of July. Insurance issue is becoming a nightmare.  I know I'm unloading but...  Oh the cruise was last month - great time, a funny story or two for another time.  Be well.
Posts.Title: Always something.... silentbell bhd1

Posts.Content: silentbell wrote: Late on this update because, umm, well I'll get to that.  Last thing was the brain mri was done on the wrong side of the brain and when we talk with the onc and trail nurse, it was the wrong machine or the settings were wrong.  So after the infusion we have to have another mri. The scanoligist (yeah, I made that word up) tells us that a week late scan is a major trial violation.  I look at my wife and smile, we don't tell her about putting off an infusion for a week for a cruise.  Habitual violators, that's us.  So now we have had way too many mri's and the insurance and hospital can't get it right without involving us and yeah, yeah.  Now for the meat and potatoes,  the onc tells us that the tx is working, one brain met is gone, 30 % shrinkage in the liver!  So I'm getting ready to do cartwheels and my wife says " I'm not going to get excited until the next scan.  ??!!??  We must not be on the same roller coaster.  Seven different treatments and heard the word stable only once.  This chemo tx is kicking the stuffing out of her (and the cancer) and she has been able to cut her pain meds in half.  Next scan is in August sometime and I'm in a holding pattern worrying about the next scan way to early. Man...  Good luck too all, this site is amazing. sideline husband Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 12:35AM silentbell wrote: Hi Barb, went back to read my post and saw all the info gaps.  My wife was on a phase 3 trial drug MK 2206, after her 2nd trmt came down with the rash from hell.  Skipped a dose and reduced the dose and had progression in the liver after starting about 6 weeks earlier(nurse said everyone experiences a rash).  21 day wait with all the scans and test before the phase 1 trial drug MM 302.  Problems with the EKG test on wednesday, went back today and still had a bad test perhaps from cold medicine so we are to try again tommorow.  Herceptin and taxol - TDM 1  -  Xeloda and tykerb - MK 2206 - MM 302 rounds out the chemo's so far.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2012 06:24AM - edited Apr 3, 2012 06:29AM by silentbell Some good info here.  I think that TDM-1 will get approved.  Herception's is the foundation that goes straight to the tumor and TDM-1 brings a type of chemo straight to the tumor.  Which means less pain and suffering with side effects.  They are currently using different types of chemo with herception/TDM-1 on trials, phase two and phase one trials.  Logic leads me to believe that since they are using this breakthrough to get different types of chemo to the tumors on different trials and TDM-1 has helped so many (unfortunately not us) , approval is a shoe in.  This info came about from the treatments at Dana Farber.  Scan results tomorrow - good or bad I am still cheering for approval. Forgot to say Phase 2 - MK 2206 and Phase 1 - MM303  or 302
Posts.Title: Hope yet for TDM1 to be approved Fitztwins bhd1

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2011 07:25AM silentbell wrote: PizzaDad Xeloda and Tykerb didn't work for my wife either.  My wife also still works, a sort of normalcy for her I guess.  I know how it feels to be a spectator and powerless.  Even when the chemos don't last very long it seems to take forever to find out if the next one will work.  My heart goes out to you and this site gives us support and helps us be hopeful.  Best of luck with the next tx.  It's the silly season and may it be a good one for your family (little ones make it a lot of fun, I remember).  The vacation's something to look forward to and I hope all goes well.  Hang in there.
